docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: Subdivision 3 Proof of wills in non-contentious proceedings [rr 25–33]

heading.title: Subdivision 3 Proof of wills in non-contentious proceedings [rr 25–33]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: Subdivision 3 Proof of wills in non-contentious proceedings [rr 25–33]

leg:heading.title: Proof of wills in non-contentious proceedings [rr 25–33]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 25] r 25 Application of Division

p.text: This Subdivision applies to proceedings in which the plaintiff seeks to prove a will.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.25.5] Onus of proof and circumstances of doubtful will validity

heading.title: Onus of proof and circumstances of doubtful will validity

p.text: A probate applicant bears the onus of establishing the validity of the will. There are a range of circumstances where the apparent validity of the will may be doubtful — eg the circumstances addressed in SCR Pts 78.26–78.33. Where there are circumstances that cast doubt on the validity of the will, the applicant must provide sufficient evidence to satisfy the court that it is proper to admit the will to probate: Re Eger; Helprin v Eger (NSWSC, Powell J, 4 February 1985, unreported, BC8500997), citing Bailey v Bailey (1924) 34 CLR 558 at 570–2; [1924] VLR 294; (1924) 30 ALR 230; BC2400030 .

Each of the approved forms of supporting affidavit require the deponent to confirm that there are no circumstances that raise doubt as to their entitlement to a grant of probate of the will: see para 15 of Forms 118, 119, 120, 121 and 122.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 26] r 26 Will not sufficiently attested

p.text: If the will contains either no attestation clause or an insufficient attestation clause, the plaintiff must file an affidavit by one or more of the attesting witnesses to the due execution of the will.
A plaintiff who is unable to comply with subrule (1) must file:
an affidavit as to the reason for the inability, and
a further affidavit by some other person who was present when the will was executed.
A plaintiff who is unable to comply with subrule (1) or (2) must file an affidavit as to:
the reason for the inability, and
either:
the signatures of the testator and the attesting witnesses, or
other facts from which it may be inferred that the will was duly executed.
The approved form for the affidavit of an attesting witness to a will is UCPR Form 132.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.26.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 6.
A will must be executed in the presence of two or more attesting witnesses, but no particular form of attestation is necessary: Succession Act 2006 s 6 .

It is not necessary for a will to have a formal attestation clause. If the will has been signed by persons other than the testator there is a rebuttable presumption that they do so as attesting witnesses: In the Estate of Wright (NSWSC, Halsham J, 9 May 1974, unreported). Where there is such a clause there is a strong presumption that the will has been duly executed. If the attestation clause is defective (or missing) a presumption of regularity still applies. The court always acts, as far as it can, in favour of the due execution of a will and on the presumption that all the statutory requirements of attestation have been met: Re Goode; Tibbits v Maclean (1891) 12 LR (NSW) Eq 41; 7 WN (NSW) 66; In the Estate of Banfield (1935) 52 WN (NSW) 167 ; In the Will of Edwards (1910) 27 WN (NSW) 185b ; In the Estate of Theakston (1956) 74 WN (NSW) 113 ; In the Will of Kimbell [1969] 1 NSWR 414; (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 614 . Clear evidence is required to rebut the presumption of due execution: Gair v Bowers (1909) 9 CLR 510; [1910] VLR 538; (1909) 15 ALR 494; BC0900031 ; Estate of Robertson [1964] NSWR 1087 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.26.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898 s 18A.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 8.
An informal document may be recognised as a person’s will, or as effecting an alteration to or revocation of a person’s will, in certain circumstances.

If the person died between 1 November 1989 and before 1 March 2008, the court’s power to accord testamentary effect to the document arose under s 18A of the Wills, Probate and Administration Act 1898.
If the person died on or after 1 March 2008, the court’s power to accord testamentary effect to the document arose under s 8 of the Succession Act 2006.

SCR rr 41–45 (in Pt 78 Div 6) outline the formal requirements where proceedings involve an application for probate or administration in relation to a will that includes an informal testamentary document.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.26.15] Knowledge and approval of contents of will

heading.title: Knowledge and approval of contents of will

p.text: The document proffered as the will of the deceased will be admitted to probate to the extent the court is satisfied that the deceased knew and approved of its contents. If certain parts of the document were not known and approved by the testator, a grant of probate may be made excluding those parts.
In determining whether an applicant for a grant has shown that the testator knew and approved the contents of the will the following settled principles will be applied:
The due execution of a will raises a presumption that the testator knew and approved of its contents: Re Harrocks [1939] P 198; [1939] 1 All ER 579; (1939) 108 LJP 86; 160 LT 324 .
Where the will has been read by or to testators the presumption that they knew and approved of its contents can be rebutted only by the clearest evidence: Gregson v Taylor [1917] P 256 .

Nevertheless, the fact that the will has been so read by the testator does not constitute conclusive evidence of knowledge and approval: Re Morris [1971] P 62; [1970] 2 WLR 865 ; Re Phelan [1971] 3 All ER 1256; [1971] 3 WLR 888; [1972] Fam 33 ; Guardian Trust & Executors Co of New Zealand Ltd v Darroch [1973] 2 NZLR 143 ; Recent Developments in NSW in the Law Relating to Wills (1993) 67 ALJ 25 by Powell J. Particularly, this is so where there is a substantial doubt as to the testator's ability to understand the will: Astridge v Pepper [1970] 1 NSWR 542 . Doubts of that kind may arise where the testator was enfeebled, illiterate or blind when the instrument was executed: Tyrrell v Painton [1894] P 151 ; Kenny v Wilson (1911) 11 SR (NSW) 460 at 469; 28 WN (NSW) 124 ; Re Eger; Helprin v Eger (NSWSC, Powell J, 4 February 1985, unreported, BC8500997); or where a literate testator executed the instrument as a marksman: Kenny v Wilson, above; Re Eger; Helprin v Eger, above.

The fact that the will has been prepared by a beneficiary will excite suspicion as to whether the testator knew and approved of its contents: Nock v Austin (1918) 25 CLR 519; 25 ALR 88; BC1800001 ; Tanner v Public Trustee [1973] 1 NZLR 68 ; Rycroft v Court [1972] WWR 372 (Can); Re Eger; Helprin v Eger (NSWSC, Powell J, 4 February 1985, unreported, BC8500997). But the will is not void merely because it was prepared by a beneficiary: Public Trustee v McKeon (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 157; 34 WN (NSW) 68b .

Words may be omitted from the proposed will. The onus is on those who seek to have probate granted with words omitted to rebut the presumption of knowledge and approval of those words which arises from the due execution of the will. Where the will, though executed by the testator, has not been read by or to the testator the relevant onus is that of the balance of probabilities: Re Fenwick [1972] VR 646 . Words may be omitted where they were mistakenly included in the document: Osborne v Smith (1960) 105 CLR 153; [1961] ALR 831; (1960) 34 ALJR 368; BC6000780 ; Fulton v Andrew (1875) LR7HL 448; [1874–80] All ER Rep 1240 ; Re Fenwick [1972] VR 646 (the testator had instructed that certain words be deleted from a draft of the will); Re Bryden [1975] Qd R 210 and Re Reynette-James [1975] 3 All ER 1037; [1976] 1 WLR 161 (where words were inadvertently included in the will); Re Phelan [1971] 3 All ER 1256; [1971] 3 WLR 888; [1972] Fam 33 and Re Luck [1977] WAR 148 (where the evidence established that the testator, in making a second will disposing of particular assets, had not intended to revoke entirely an earlier will dealing with all his assets).

It is not permissible to grant probate with words added to the testator’s will: Re Horrocks [1939] P 198; [1939] 1 All ER 579; (1939) 108 LJP 86; 160 LT 324 ; Re Hemburrow [1969] VR 764 ; Recent Developments in NSW in the Law Relating to Wills (1993) 67 ALJ 25 by Powell J.

If the words omitted include a revocation clause in a later will, the effect of the omission is to enable probate to be granted of an earlier will, and enlarge the testamentary material which is admitted to probate: Re Tait [1957] VR 405; [1957] ALR 862 (two clauses from an earlier will were mistakenly omitted from a later will — both wills were admitted to probate with a declaration that the revocation clause in the second was not intended to, and did not, revoke the two clauses in the earlier will.

Testators must be able to understand the extent of their property, the claims to which they ought to give effect and the persons who are the beneficiaries of the dispositions in the will: Banks v Goodfellow (1870) LR5QB 549 at 565 ; Timbury v Coffee (1941) 66 CLR 277 at 280; 15 ALJR 159b; BC4190106 ; Bull v Fulton (1942) 66 CLR 295; [1942] ALR 221; (1942) 16 ALJR 186; BC4200025 .

If the will has been duly executed and is rational in its dispositions the testator will be presumed to have had testamentary capacity, in the absence of evidence to the contrary: Symes v Green (1859) 1 Sw & Tr 401; 164 ER 785; Sutton v Sadler (1857) 3 CBNS 87; 26 LJCP 284; 30 LTOS 65; 140 ER 671 . In particular, the testator will be presumed to have been sane, ie unaffected by a relevant mental illness, until the contrary is shown: Burrows v Burrows (1827) 1 Hag Ecc 109.

In order to demonstrate that the testator lacked capacity it must be shown that the testator's mental faculties were so affected that they were incapable of properly undertaking the task of properly disposing of their property: Singh v Amirchand [1948] AC 161; [1948] 1 All ER 152 ; Bailey v Bailey (1924) 34 CLR 558 at 570–2; [1924] VLR 294; (1924) 30 ALR 230; BC2400030 ; Re Eger; Helprin v Eger (NSWSC, Powell J, 4 February 1985, unreported, BC8500997). The evidence must show that the testator was more than merely eccentric: Hendy v Jenkins (1901) 1 SR (NSW) B&P 34; 18 WN (NSW) 140.

Considerations that may provide a basis for questioning (but do not necessarily demonstrate) a testator’s capacity include the exclusion of persons naturally having a claim on the testator's bounty: Banks v Goodfellow (1870) LR5QB 549 ; extreme age or sickness: Singh v Amirchand [1948] AC 161; [1948] 1 All ER 152 ; Boreham v Prince Henry Hospital (1955) 29 ALJR 179 ; Kenny v Wilson (1911) 11 SR (NSW) 460; 28 WN (NSW) 124 ; or alcoholism: Timbury v Coffee (1941) 66 CLR 277; 15 ALJR 159b; BC4190106 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.26.25] Mental illness, legal incapacity and testamentary capacity

heading.title: Mental illness, legal incapacity and testamentary capacity

p.text: Mental illness may, depending on its nature and severity, provide a basis to question the testator’s capacity. But the illness is only significant in so far as it provides good reason to conclude that it in fact adversely influenced testator’s proper disposition of their property: Tipper v Moore (1911) 13 CLR 248; 18 ALR 341; BC1100006 . A diagnosis of mental illness does not necessarily exclude, and may be consistent with, the testator having made their will during a period of lucidity when they were well able to fulfil the requirements as to testamentary capacity: Kenny v Wilson (1911) 11 SR (NSW) 460; 28 WN (NSW) 124 ; Landers v Landers (1914) 19 CLR 222; BC1490114 ; Nock v Austin (1918) 25 CLR 519; 25 ALR 88; BC1800001 ; Bailey v Bailey (1924) 34 CLR 558 at 570–2; [1924] VLR 294; (1924) 30 ALR 230; BC2400030 ; Bull v Fulton, above.

A person’s general legal incapacity is not itself probative of a lack of testamentary capacity. A person who is subject to an order under the NSW Trustee and Guardian Act 2009, committing the management of the person's estate to the NSW Trustee and Guardian, is not conclusively presumed to have lacked testamentary capacity: Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Fairlie-Cunninghame; Estate of Service (1993) 32 NSWLR 377; BC9301766 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 27] r 27 Blind or illiterate testator’s will or will at another’s direction

leg:heading.title: Blind or illiterate testator’s will or will at another’s direction

p.text: If the will was or appears to have been signed by:
a blind or illiterate testator, or
some other person at the testator’s direction,
the affidavit in support must include all available evidence as to the manner in which the will was executed and as to whether the testator knew and approved its contents.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 28] r 28 Date of execution

p.text: If the will is undated, the affidavit in support must include evidence establishing the date of its execution.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 28A] r 28A Affidavit of additional assets: cf s 81A (2) of the Probate Act

leg:heading.title: Affidavit of additional assets: cf s 81A (2) of the Probate Act

p.text: [s 28A rep Amendment 421 of 2012 Sch 1[1], effective 21 January 2013]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 29] r 29 Interlineations, obliterations and alterations

p.text: If:
there is any interlineation, obliteration or alteration in the will, and
the interlineation, obliteration or alteration is not duly authenticated or otherwise validated,
the affidavit in support must include evidence establishing that the interlineation, obliteration or alteration was made before the will was executed.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.29.1] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 14.

Subject to some qualifications, and special circumstances, alterations made to a will after its execution are ineffective, unless the alterations were executed in the manner required for the will itself: see Succession Act 2006 s 14 (for alterations to wills made on or after 1 March 2008).

Any alteration to a will is presumed to have been made after the testator executed the will: Re Hume's Will (1888) 4 WN (NSW) 131a ; In the Will of Phillips (1932) 50 WN (NSW) 2 ; Greville v Tylee (1851) 7 Moo PCC 320; 13 ER 904 ; In the Will of Fenton (1900) 17 WN (NSW) 145a . The presumption may be rebutted by internal evidence of the document itself or by external evidence, for example, evidence of declarations which the testator made before or at the time of execution of the will: In the Goods of Sykes (1873) LR 3 P & D 26. Apart from any specific statutory provisions, the presumption is not rebutted by the placing of a date next to an alteration so as to show that it was made before the execution of the will: In the Goods of Adamson (1875) LR 3 P & D 253. If the presumption of subsequent alteration is not rebutted, and the original words are apparent, probate will be granted of the will as it originally stood: In the Goods of Beaman (1840) 2 Curt 369; In the Will of Phillips (1932) 50 WN (NSW) 2 ; In the Will of Johnston (1904) 21 WN (NSW) 157a ; Re Estate of Kirs (decd) (1990) 55 SASR 61 . If the original words are not apparent, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to show what they were: Ffinch v Combe [1894] P 191 ; In the Will of Baker (1922) 39 WN (NSW) 257 . Probate of the will then be granted in blank: In the Goods of Livock (1838) 1 Curt 906; In the Goods of Ibbetson (1839) 2 Curt 337.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 30] r 30 Documents referred to or attached

p.text: If:
the will contains a reference to a document that suggests that the document forms part of the will, or
there are marks on the will from which it appears that a document has been attached to it,
the affidavit in support must include all available evidence in regard to those circumstances.

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.30.1] Document incorporated in a will

p.text: If the will itself has been properly attested it may incorporate another document, and that additional document does not require separate attestation. The only necessity is that the will has accurately and sufficiently identified the incorporated document: Burton v Newbery (1875) 1 Ch D 234 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 31] r 31 Part of will paper torn off or cut off

leg:heading.title: Part of will paper torn off or cut off

p.text: If it appears that any part of the material on which the will was written has been torn or cut off, the affidavit in support must include all available evidence (including the torn or cut-off part) in regard to those circumstances.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78 r 32] r 32 Burning, tearing or other sign of revocation

leg:heading.title: Burning, tearing or other sign of revocation

p.text: If:
it appears that there may have been an attempt to destroy the will by burning, tearing or otherwise, or
there are other circumstances that suggest that the testator may have revoked the will,
the affidavit in support must include all available evidence in regard to those circumstances.
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.32.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 11.
A testator’s will may be revoked, and its dispositions rendered ineffective (subject to any statutory modification) in a range of circumstances. These include:
marriage or divorce
a later will
a duly executed written instrument
partial destruction
alteration or other dealing.
See generally Succession Act 2006 s 11 (revocation after 1 March 2008).

In addition, specific dispositions in a will may be adeemed where their subject matter has ceased to exist as part of the testator's property at death, or where a legacy given by the will is adeemed by a gift the testator made before their death that is intended to operate either wholly or partially in substitution for the provision in the will: Re Pollock (1885) 28 Ch D 552 ; Gilder v Fairweather (1943) 44 SR (NSW) 229; 61 WN (NSW) 50 .
Legislation cited in [SCR Pt 78.32.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Succession Act 2006 s 11(1)(d), s 11(1)(f).

Revocation depends on the testator’s intention: Smith v Cunningham (1823) 1 Add 448; 162 ER 158 ; Powell v Powell (1866) LR1P&D 209b. There is no presumption of revocation: Harris v Berrall (1858) 1 Sw & Tr 153; Sprigge v Sprigge (1868) LR1P&D 608; Benson v Benson (1870) LR2P&D 172. The intention to revoke must be a clearly proved, and present, intention to revoke the previous will: Kellett v Kellett (1868) LR 3 HL 160; Re Wilcock; Kay v Dewhirst [1898] 1 Ch 95 ; Clayebury v Beckett (1851) 14 Beav 583. For example, the use of such words as “last will” in a document does not necessarily import a revocation of all previous wills: In the Will of Cullen (1907) 7 SR (NSW) 29; 24 WN (NSW) 23a .

A document that declares an intention to revoke a will must itself be executed with the same formalities as are required for the execution of a will: Succession Act 2006 s 11(1)(d) . Writing words such as “destroyed” or “cancelled” on the bottom of a will, or scribbling over the attestation clause and the signatures of the attesting witnesses and the testator, may provide evidence of revocation — but only if the court is satisfied of the testator’s intention to revoke: see Succession Act s 11(1)(f) and compare Re Will of Whitehead (1882) 3 LR (NSW) Eq 21 ; In the Will of Gordon (1898) 9 BC (NSW) 12.

The testator’s intention to revoke must be unconditional. Conduct does not involve an effective revocation if the testator intended that the revocation was conditional on the achievement of another purpose, and that purpose has failed. This is known as the doctrine of dependent relative revocation: Ex parte Earl of Ilchester (1803) 7 Bes 348 at 372; 32 ER 142. It is most readily illustrated by situations where a testator has destroyed a will in the erroneous belief that by doing so they would revive an earlier will. In such a case the court, if it satisfied that the testator did not intend to die intestate, may hold the apparent revocation to be ineffective: Ward v Crook (1876) 17 LR B & P 64; Bowman v Butler (1894) 15 LR (NSW) B & P 7; In the Estate of Niven (1921) 21 SR (NSW) 702; 38 WN (NSW) 223 ; In the Will of Simpson (1933) 50 WN (NSW) 83 ; Re Will of Mills (decd) [1968] 2 NSWR 393; (1968) 70 SR (NSW) 36; 88 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 74 ; Re Wright [1970] QWN 28 ; Re Jones (decd) [1976] Ch 200; [1976] 1 All ER 593; [1976] 2 WR 457 ; Re Ott (1972) 24 DLR (3d) 517.

Revocation by “burning, tearing or otherwise” depends on both the testator’s capacity and intention. There is revocation where the person was of unsound mind: In the Will of Thompson (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 74 ; or was drunk: Brunt v Brunt (1873) LR 3 P & D 37. Nor does conduct constitute an effective revocation unless the court is satisfied the testator intended to revoke their previous will.

No test has been laid down as to the extent of destruction required to revoke effectively a will, but it has been held that it is sufficient if its essence as a will though not the materials of which it is composed, are destroyed: Hobbs v Knight (1838) 1 Curt 768.

Conversely, neither total nor substantial destruction of the will is necessarily determinative of the testator’s intention to revoke their will: Clarkson v Clarkson (1862) 2 Sw & Tr 497; 164 ER 1090; In the Goods of Thornton (1890) 14 PD 82; Cheese v Lovejoy (1876) 2 PD 251 (total destruction); Killick's Will (1886) 2 WN (NSW) 66; Re Wright [1970] QWN 28 (partial destruction by tearing up). For example, there is no revocation where a testator destroys their will through inadvertence: Burtenshaw v Gilbert (1774) 1 Cowp 49; 98 ER 961 , under the belief that it is useless: Beardsley v Lacey (1897) 67 LJP 35; 78 LT 25; 14 TLR 140 , or invalid: Giles v Warren (1872) LR2P&D 401, in the belief that it has already been revoked: Scott v Scott (1859) 1 Sw & Tr 258; 164 ER 719; In the Will of Cotton; Giblin v O'Connor and Gallagher (1863) 2 SCR 123, in the mistaken that they had made another will: Lippe v Hedderwick (1922) 31 CLR 148; BC2290103 ; or on the basis of any other erroneous factual assumption: Campbell v French (1797) 3 Ves 321; 30 ER 1033 .

level.toc-caption: [SCR Pt 78.32.25] Revocation by a subsequent will or codicil

heading.title: Revocation by a subsequent will or codicil

p.text: A later will or codicil will revoke an earlier will if either (i) it expressly revokes the earlier will, or (ii) the two must be incapable of concurrent operation: In the Will of Cullen (1907) 7 SR (NSW) 29; 24 WN (NSW) 23a ; In the Will of Gilbert, Re (1905) 22 WN (NSW) 186 .

Where a codicil by its terms revokes portion of a will the provisions of the will are not to be disturbed further than is necessary to give effect to the terms of the codicil: Re Day; Kavanagh v Day (1907) 7 SR (NSW) 484; 24 WN (NSW) 117b ; In Will of Jackson; Jackson v Jackson (1868) 7 SCR (NSW) Eq 28; Re Lawrence's Will Trust [1972] Ch 418 .
There is no presumption that a later will which is proved to have been destroyed revoked an earlier will: In the Will of Johnson (1894) 15 LR (NSW) B & P 26.

If there is evidence that testators in executing a later will did so with the intention that it should only operate as a codicil to their earlier will then any words of revocation contained in the second document will be ignored: Re Goods of Oswald (1874) LR 3 P & D 162; Marklen v Turner (1900) 17 TLR 10; Re Goods of Moore [1892] P 378; In the Goods of Swords (decd) [1952] P 368; [1952] 2 All ER 281 ; see also In the Will of FJ Page [1969] 1 NSWR 471; (1969) 90 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 6 where both wills purported to be the testator's last will and both contained revocation clauses.

But if a later will has been duly executed, and deals with all the testator's property, it will operate to revoke all earlier wills, whether or not it contains a revocation clause. This is because the later will, in dealing with all of the testator’s property, is taken to be in substitution for any previously executed testamentary document: Henfrey v Henfrey (1842) 4 Moo PCC 29; 13 ER 211 ; Dempsey v Lawson (1877) 2 PD 98; [1874–80] All ER Rep 296 ; Chichester v Quatrefages [1895] P 186 ; Re the Will of Eagles [1990] 2 Qd R 501 .

If it appears that the will is or may be wholly or partly inoperative, whether by reason of the executors and beneficiaries all predeceasing the testator or otherwise, the affidavit in support must include evidence as to what persons would be entitled to distribution of the estate on intestacy.
